com.github.mucaho.jnetemu

Class SimpleWanEmulator

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.mucaho.jnetemu.DatagramWanEmulator
      • com.github.mucaho.jnetemu.SimpleWanEmulator

  • public class SimpleWanEmulator
extends DatagramWanEmulator
    This class provides a simple implementation of a network emulator. It introduces packet-latency, -jitter, -loss and -duplication to incoming packets, before relaying them.
    The specific emulation parameters can be tuned with the appropriate getters / setters, before starting the emulation or while emulation is already active.

                         SocketAddress socketAddressA,

        socketAddressA - one socket address
        socketAddressB - the other socket address

    • Method Detail

      • loss

        public float loss()
        Get the chance of a packet being lost. A value of 0.00f means no packet loss, a value of 1.00f means every packet will be lost. Defaults to 0.10f (10%).
        Returns:
        the packet loss fraction

      • loss

        public void loss(float loss)
        Set the chance of a packet being lost. A value of 0.0f means no packet loss, a value of 1.0f means every packet will be lost. Defaults to 0.10f (10%).
        Parameters:
        loss - the new packet loss fraction

      • duplication

        public float duplication()
        Get the chance of a packet being duplicated. A value of 0.00f means no packets will be duplicated, a value of 1.00f means every packet will be duplicated infinitely. Defaults to 0.03f (3%).
        Returns:
        the packet duplication fraction

      • duplication

        public void duplication(float duplication)
        Set the chance of a packet being duplicated. A value of 0.00f means no packets will be duplicated, a value of 1.00f means every packet will be duplicated infinitely. Defaults to 0.03f (3%).
        Parameters:
        duplication - the new packet duplication fraction

      • delay

        public int delay()
        Get the base delay between sending from one peer to receiveing on the other one. The actual delay will randomly vary between baseDelay +/- jitter. Defaults to 175 ms.
        Returns:
        the base delay in ms

      • delay

        public void delay(int delay)
        Set the base delay between sending from one peer to receiveing on the other one. The actual delay will randomly vary between baseDelay +/- jitter. Defaults to 175 ms.
        Parameters:
        delay - the new base delay in ms

      • jitter

        public int jitter()
        Get the delay jitter between sending from one peer to receiveing on the other one. The actual delay will randomly vary between baseDelay +/- jitter. Defaults to +/- 75 ms.
        Returns:
        the delay jitter in ms

      • computeNetworkConditions

        protected void computeNetworkConditions(long timeNow,
                                        Collection<? extends DatagramWanEmulator.Scheduled> scheduled,
                                        List<Long> scheduledTimes)
        Compute network conditions. Actual implementation given in subclasses.
        This method will be called once per incoming packet and computes the network conditions for the outgoing packet. At any time it is guaranteed to be called from a single thread only, thus implementing classes should not worry about threading issues.
        Specified by:
        computeNetworkConditions in class DatagramWanEmulator
        Parameters:
        timeNow - the current low-resolution system time in ms, that should be used by all time-dependent computations. It represents the difference between the current time and midnight, 01.01.1970 UTC.
        scheduled - a read-only ordered collection containing already scheduled packets. Note that packets being duplicated are represented multiple times in this collection. This is provided as additional information for computing network conditions.
        scheduledTimes - a writable list that should be filled with zero or more scheduled times at which the incoming packet will be relayed. Scheduled times are given as the difference between current time (timeNow) and midnight, 01.01.1970 UTC.
        • A zero-length list indicates packet gets dropped.
        • A list with a single element indicates at which time to relay the incoming packet.
        • A list with n elements indicates that the packet will be duplicated n-1 times. These duplicates will be sent according to the time values provided.
